docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 RULES, PRACTICE NOTES AND FORMS [ss 8–17]

heading.title: DIVISION 1 RULES, PRACTICE NOTES AND FORMS [ss 8–17]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 RULES, PRACTICE NOTES AND FORMS [ss 8–17]

p.text: There is to be a Uniform Rules Committee comprising 12 members, of whom:
one is to be the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court or a Judge of the Supreme Court nominated for the time being by the Chief Justice, and
one is to be the President of the Court of Appeal or a Judge of Appeal nominated for the time being by the President, and
two are to be Judges of the Supreme Court appointed by the Chief Justice, and
one is to be the Chief Judge of the Land and Environment Court or a Judge nominated for the time being by the Chief Judge, and

one is to be the President of the Industrial Relations Commission or a judicial member of the Commission (within the meaning of the Industrial Relations Act 1996) nominated for the time being by the President, and
one is to be the Chief Judge of the District Court or a Judge of the District Court nominated for the time being by the Chief Judge, and
one is to be a Judge of the District Court appointed by the Chief Judge, and
one is to be the Chief Magistrate or a Magistrate nominated for the time being by the Chief Magistrate, and
one is to be a Magistrate appointed by the Chief Magistrate, and
one is to be a barrister appointed by the Bar Council, and
one is to be a solicitor appointed by the Law Society Council.

[subs (1) am Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.3] , effective 4 December 2006; Act 56 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2[1], [2], effective 28 January 2008 ; Act 77 of 2009 Sch 2.6[1], [2], effective 3 November 2009]
Schedule 2 has effect with respect to the constitution and procedure of the Uniform Rules Committee.

The Uniform Rules Committee may make rules, not inconsistent with this Act, for or with respect to any matter that by this Act is required or permitted to be prescribed by rules or that is necessary or convenient to be prescribed by rules for carrying out or giving effect to this Act.

Without limiting subsection (1), rules under this section may make provision, in relation to all civil proceedings in respect of which a court has jurisdiction (however arising), for or with respect to the matters specified in Schedule 3 .
On the commencement of this section, the rules set out in Schedule 7 are taken to have been made under this section, and may be amended and repealed accordingly.

The rules made under this section may authorise or require the use of an electronic case management system established under clause 2 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000 in relation to any proceedings in a court in respect of which the use of such a system is authorised by an order in force under clause 3 of Schedule 1 to that Act.
[subs (4) am Act 119 of 2010 Sch 2.10, effective 7 January 2011]

This section does not give power to make rules with respect to any matter for which rules may be made under section 38 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 or any matter relating to costs that is regulated by Part 3.2 of that Act.
This section does not limit the operation of section 78 of the Interpretation Act 1987.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 10] s 10 Rules of court taken to include uniform rules

leg:heading.title: Rules of court taken to include uniform rules

p.text: Rules of court are taken to include the uniform rules to the extent to which they are applicable in that court.
Subsection (1) does not authorise the person or body having power to make local rules to amend or repeal a uniform rule in its application to that court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 11] s 11 Relationship between uniform rules and local rules

leg:heading.title: Relationship between uniform rules and local rules

p.text: The uniform rules prevail over any provision of any local rules unless the uniform rules expressly provide that the provision of the local rules is to prevail.
One rule prevails over another, as referred to in subsection (1), to the extent only of any inconsistency between them.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 12] s 12 Officers of the court may exercise functions conferred by uniform rules

leg:heading.title: Officers of the court may exercise functions conferred by uniform rules

p.text: Without limiting any other functions he or she may exercise, a registrar or other officer of any court may exercise any function conferred on such an officer by the uniform rules.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 13] s 13 Officers of the court may be authorised to exercise court’s functions

leg:heading.title: Officers of the court may be authorised to exercise court’s functions

p.text: The senior judicial officer of any court may, by instrument in writing:

direct that any function of the court under this Act or any other Act or law in respect of which the court has jurisdiction (including any rules of court) may be exercised by such registrars or other officers of the court, and in such circumstances and subject to such conditions, as are specified in the instrument, and
vary or revoke any such instrument.
[s 13 am Act 60 of 2012 Sch 3[1], effective 10 September 2012]
This section does not limit any provision of the Act by which the court is constituted with respect to the exercise of the court’s functions.

The powers of the Court of Appeal Registrar, Supreme Court Registrars and the Supreme Court Chief Clerk are the subject of directions under the present section. Those directions are set out at [17,000] , [17,005] and [17,010] (immediately after the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999).
Legislation cited in [s 13.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 DCA s 18FB.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 DCR Pt 43A r 1.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 1.10.

The powers of the Judicial Registrar of the District Court are the subject of special provision in DCA s 18FB , DCR Pt 43A r 1 and UCPR r 1.10 . Under DCR Pt 43A r 1 and UCPR r 1.10 , the Judicial Registrar has all of the powers of the court — except its contempt powers and powers relating to the exercise of criminal jurisdiction. The powers of registrars in the District Court are also the subject of a direction under the present section. The direction is set out at [30,000] (immediately after the District Court Rules).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 14] s 14 Court may dispense with rules in particular cases

leg:heading.title: Court may dispense with rules in particular cases

p.text: In relation to particular civil proceedings, the court may, by order, dispense with any requirement of rules of court if satisfied that it is appropriate to do so in the circumstances of the case.
Legislation cited in [s 14.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 42.3.

The power conferred by the present section is limited to dispensing with rules that impose requirements with which the parties must otherwise comply. It does not permit a court to circumvent limitations or restrictions in any powers that have been conferred by other rules: Jeffery & Katauskas Pty Ltd v SST Consulting Pty Ltd; Jeffery & Katauskas Pty Ltd v Rickard Constructions Pty Ltd (subject to Deed of Company Arrangement) (2009) 239 CLR 75; 260 ALR 34; [2009] HCA 43; BC200909275 (no power to circumvent the former UCPR r 42.3 prohibition on costs orders against non-parties); Malouf v Prince (No 2) [2010] NSWCA 51; BC201001570 at [22].

level.toc-caption: [s 14.5] Dispensing with the requirements of the Rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 14.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(1).

heading.title: Dispensing with the requirements of the Rules

p.text: The court’s function is to do justice between the parties. The object of the CPA and the UCPR is to conduce to that end and facilitate the “just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings”: see CPA s 56(1) . The attainment of that overriding purpose ought not be compromised by excessive rigidity in the application of either the CPA or the UCPR: Cropper v Smith (1884) 26 Ch D 700 at 710 ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379 at 391; 104 ALR 165 ; Clune v Watson [1882] Tarl 75 (“the rules must be the servant not the master of the court”); Re Coles & Ravenshear [1907] 1 KB 1 at 4 (the relation of the rules … to the work of justice is... that of handmaid rather than mistress”); see also Outboard Marine Australia Pty Ltd v Byrnes [1974] 1 NSWLR 27 at 30 ; Re Testro Bros Consolidated Ltd [1965] VR 18 ; Re Sydney Formworks Pty Ltd (in liq) [1965] NSWR 646 ; Re AJ Benjamin Ltd (in liq) [1969] 2 NSWR 374; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 107 ; Garrard (t/as Arthur Anderson & Co) v Email Furniture Pty Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 662 at 681 ; Ferrand v Bradford Corp (1856) 8 De GM & G 93 at 95; 44 ER 324 at 325. Despite the potential flexibility that this policy contemplates, a person who seeks dispensation from compliance with the Rules bears the onus of satisfying the court that the dispensation sought is appropriate in the particular case. Generally this will require the party to offer a proper reason for, or explanation of, past or anticipated non-compliance (as the case may be): Iovanescu v McDermott [2004] NSWCA 106; BC200407393 at [3] , [5] per Young CJ in Eq; Morres v Papuan Rubber and Trading Co Ltd (1914) 14 SR (NSW) 141 at 144 .

level.toc-caption: [s 14.10] Before or after the occasion for compliance

heading.title: Before or after the occasion for compliance

p.text: The court may dispense with the requirements of the Rules even after non-compliance has occurred: FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268; 77 ALR 411 at 283–4; [1998] HCA 13; BC8802594 (extension after expiry of time); Emanuele v Australian Securities Commission (1997) 188 CLR 114; 144 ALR 359; [1997] HCA 20; BC9702205 (leave to proceed); Australasian Memory Pty Ltd v Brien (1998) 45 NSWLR 111; BC9805700 (extension of time under corporations legislation); Re Testro Bros Consolidated Ltd [1965] VR 18 (orders may be made “nunc pro tunc”); Re Sydney Formworks Pty Ltd (in liq) [1965] NSWR 646 ; Re AJ Benjamin Ltd (in liq) [1969] 2 NSWR 374; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 107 ; Harding v Bourke (2000) 48 NSWLR 598; [2000] NSWCA 60; BC200001287 at [16] and [25] (late application for extension of time to re-instate dismissed proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [s 14.15] Examples of the power to dispense with compliance

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 14.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

heading.title: Examples of the power to dispense with compliance

p.text: The power conferred by the present section can be used in a wide range of circumstances. One obvious circumstance for the exercise of the power is to extend time for the commencement, or service, of proceedings: Ryan v Triguboff [1976] 1 NSWLR 588 at 606 (an application under the Justices Act 1902); Pinkstone v Goldrick [1979] 1 NSWLR 279 ; contra Edens v Cleary [1975] 1 NSWLR 278 at 281 . And UCPR r 1.12 specifically permits the extension or abridgment of times fixed by either the UCPR or by judgments and orders in proceedings. But the power to dispense with the requirements of the UCPR is not limited to such situations. It may, for example, permit reliance on matters not formally raised in an originating process or motion: Galletta v Walter [1977] 1 NSWLR 1 (plaintiff permitted to argue grounds not expressly raised in a stated case). However, the section only permits dispensation consistent with the overriding purpose referred to in CPA s 56 . Consequently it does not authorise dispensation where non compliance may operate to the detriment of another party. Consistent with this limitation it would be inappropriate, for example, to use the present section to regularise substituted service effected contrary to the UCPR. This is so even if service had purportedly been effected in accordance with an order, if the order itself had been irregularly made: Chappell v Coyle (1985) 2 NSWLR 73 at 86 .
Legislation cited in [s 14.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 465A.

In some instances the relevant requirement may be partly based on statutory provisions. For example, Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 465A requires an applicant under specfied sections to “advertise the application as prescribed by the rules”. In these instances, while the present section of the CPA would permit an order dispensing with provisions of the Rules that govern te manner of advertising it would not permit totally dispensing with the statutory requirement to advertise: Bonehill Pty Ltd v Arrowfield Wines Pty Ltd (1996) 14 ACLC 1545 .
Subject to rules of court, the senior judicial officer of the court may issue practice notes for that court in relation to civil proceedings to which this Act applies.
A practice note must be published in the Gazette.
[subs (2) subst Act 56 of 2009 ; Sch 4.11, effective 17 July 2009]
Sections 40 and 41 of the Interpretation Act 1987 apply to a practice note in the same way as they apply to a statutory rule.
[subs (3) insrt Act 56 of 2009 ; Sch 4.11, effective 17 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [s 15.5] Formalities and validity of Practice Notes

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 15.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 15(2).
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 ss 40, 41.

heading.title: Formalities and validity of Practice Notes

p.text: Practice Notes must be published in the Gazette: CPA s 15(2) . They must also be tabled before each House of Parliament within 14 sitting days, and are subject to Parliamentary disallowance: Interpretation Act 1987 ss 40 and 41 .
Legislation cited in [s 15.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 45.1–45.14.
Practice Notes for each of the various courts to which the CPA applies are set out elsewhere, as indicated in the following list.
Practice Notes dealing specifically with case management are listed at [2.3.20] .
The special lists in the Supreme Court and the District Court, and the related Practice Notes, are dealt with in UCPR rr 45.1–45.14 .

General Practice Notes — SC Gen 1 (see vol 2 at [SC Gen 1] . This note operates as a Table of Contents and provides status information about the currency and history of all Practice Notes in the court).
Equity Practice Notes — SC Eq 1–8 (see vol 2 at [SC Eq 1]–[SC Eq 8] .)
See vol 2 at [DC (Civil) 1]–[DC (Civil) 14] .
See vol 2 at [LC 1 of 2008] – [LC Civ 1 of 2011] .
See http://www.dustdiseasestribunal.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/ddt/ddt_practice_procedure.html .
See Local Government Planning and Environment Service Vol B, LexisNexis, Sydney, 1999 to date (looseleaf) at [259,001] ff; see also http://www.lec.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lec/practice_notes.html .

The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court has issued several policy statements relating to a range of matters that fall outside the scope of individual case management dealt with in the CPA, UCPR and Practice Notes. The policies below outline the Court's expectations of parties and the general public on matters falling outside the scope of case management. Current policy statements of the Supreme Court cover the following matters:
Court attire
Delays in reserved judgments
Release of statistics, data and information
Media recordings in court
Identity theft and anonymisation
Courtroom use of phones and PDAs.
See http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/supremecourt/sco2_supremecourtpolicies.html .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 16] s 16 Court may give directions in circumstances not covered by rules

leg:heading.title: Court may give directions in circumstances not covered by rules

p.text: In relation to particular civil proceedings, the court may give directions with respect to any aspect of practice or procedure for which rules of court or practice notes do not provide.
Anything done in accordance with such a direction (including the commencing of proceedings and the taking of any step in proceedings) is taken to have been validly done.
Legislation cited in [s 16.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 14.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 1.8.

This section complements the discretion in CPA s 14 to dispense with the requirements of the rules. It expresses what would otherwise be included within the “incidental” power of the courts namely, their power to give directions where there is no specific procedure, either in the relevant Act, rules or forms, that deals with the particular application or proceeding — notwithstanding that it is a matter that is clearly within the substantive jurisdiction of the court. In such a case the court (and the parties) must do the best that they can in the circumstances — which may involve devising “ad hoc” procedures: Browne v Cmr for Railways (1935) 36 SR (NSW) 21 at 29 per Jordan CJ (the judge must do “the best he can with the means he has available”); applying Edgar v Greenwood [1910] VLR 137 at 145 . This principle has been applied in many cases: see Inland Revenue Cmrs v Joicey [1913] 1 KB 445 at 451 , 454–6 (court “may direct what manner or form of procedure is to be followed, and any step taken in accordance with a direction so given shall, for the purposes of the proceedings, be regular and sufficient”) Hawke v Edwards (No 2) (1947) 48 SR (NSW) 234 at 235; 65 WN (NSW) 47 at 47–8 ; Hoban v Davey [1972] 1 NSWLR 59 ; Bogeta Pty Ltd v Wales [1977] 1 NSWLR 139 at 148 . There is a similar power under r 1.8 of Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 — see [15,035] .
Subject to the uniform rules, the Uniform Rules Committee:
may approve forms for documents to be used in connection with civil proceedings, and

in the case of documents filed with a court, or issued by a court, by means of an ECM system within the meaning of the Electronic Transactions Act 2000, may approve the format in which such documents are to be filed or issued.
Copies of the approved forms are to be made available for public inspection at each registry of the court concerned and on the court’s internet website.
If a form is approved in relation to a document to be used in connection with proceedings in a court, a document that is filed with or issued by the court is to be in that form.
See section 80 of the Interpretation Act 1987 with respect to compliance with approved forms.
Legislation cited in [s 17.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Land and Environment Court Act 1979 s 77A(1).
The approved forms for general use in civil proceedings are set out behind the guide card “Forms”.
The approved forms are also available on, and can be completed from, the Lawlink website at: http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/spu/ll_ucpr.nsf/pages/ucpr_forms .

A small number of additional forms, approved under Land and Environment Court Act 1979 s 77A(1) , apply to proceedings in the Land and Environment Court from 1 July 2008. Those forms can also be found on the Lawlink website at http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/spu/ll_ucpr.nsf/pages/ucpr_forms .
The Lawlink website also contains general information and guidelines about the use of the approved forms: http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/spu/ll_ucpr.nsf/pages/ucpr_form_info .
Legislation cited in [s 17.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 s 80(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.10, r 34.1.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 14.
Use of the approved forms is both efficient and typically, a matter of practical convenience.
The approved forms should only be used in the situations contemplated by the rules to which the particular form relates: The Cap Bon [1967] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 543 at 548.
If an approved form does not fully reflect the scope of the apparently relevant rule, it applies subject to, and cannot limit, the operation of the rule.

If there is no approved form for a particular procedure or application, its absence does not render the relevant provision ineffective: Catlow v Accident Compensation Commission [1989] VR 214 (no form prescribed for the exercise of a right of appeal). In such a case the procedure must be moulded to suit the particular circumstances: Attorney-General (Ontario) v Daly [1924] AC 1011 at 1015 ; Moate v Dartnell (1947) 65 WN (NSW) 9 .

Substantial, rather than strict compliance with the approved forms is required: see Interpretation Act 1987 s 80(1) . The use of a wrong form will not invalidate the action it evidences if there has been substantial compliance with the requirements of the relevant rule and a reasonable recipient is unlikely to have been misled by its contents: Welker v Rinehart [2012] NSWSC 839; BC201205570 (notice to produce for inspection under UCPR r 21.10 issued using form 24 relating to production to the court under UCPR r 34.1 — notice substantially complied with the requirements of UCPR r 21.10 ).
Departures from the approved forms may be necessary from time to time to accommodate the proper application of the rules to particular situations: R v Baines (1840) 12 Ad & El 210 at 226; 113 ER 792.
